questions.question_text: When importing spreadsheet data into ServiceNow, what is the first step in the process?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Load data: Navigate to System Import Sets -> Load
1. Load data: Navigate to System Import Sets -> Load

I am with E option, this is the write one, the first step in the process of importing data is Define data source, if you go to Navigation bar and type import data set, you see the module is data source this define where the data come " fetch the data from excel to this staging source.

Selected Answer: E
The Anwser is Not C because you can also create import Set instead of Select one so there is no way either of those two anwsers were correct.
It is also not D since another question(Q.322) with the excat question text doesn't have the option'Load Data', and I am pretty sure you dont load data from the beginning the data is loaded after you hit submit. So the only anwser seems right would be E "Define Data Source"

comments.content: no no no no no no

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Gonna have to opt for Load Data. If I already have a spreadsheet where the data is defined, what do I do next? I type Load Data in the app navigator. What next? I create an import set. What next? I choose the source of my data. Clearly the answer is D. If I wanted to start before I knew what the data was then I would select E. However, since the question states that I already have that in the form of a spreadsheet then the answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D. 

"Import Sets" Is under 
"System Import Sets > Advanced > Import Sets" 
Which if you create a new instance is "Empty" & has no way to Load Data. Import Sets only shows you the imported data sources.

Under All menu - The "Integration - Imports" drop down is called "System Import Sets" Load Data is the Module that begins an import to ServiceNow. 

After filling out the form & clicking submit it states "Next Steps...." & provides the following links. 

Import Sets - Go to the import Sets for this data load.
Loaded Data.
Create Transformation Map. 
Import Logs.
Right Ans IS option E

Bit naughty this one and I'd imagine these options wouldnt be the same. If you browse, you have to select "Select Import Set" before you select "Load Data" but you could also type Load Data and you could select that without selecting "Select Import Set"

Selected Answer: C
I would go with C here. The Module you use to load data is indeed called "Load Data" module, but once you open it, the first thing it asks you to do is select (or create a new ) Import Set table, then you need to choose a data source, and only after you do these 2 things you can click "Submit" which Loads the data....

Selected Answer: C
You have to create or select an Import Set prior to selecting the Data Source. Once the Import set is defined you update or add the data source.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is correct

Selected Answer: A
option A is the example used in the Data schema overview lesson under Additional SN fundamentals content for Sys Admins & Developers.

Selected Answer: A
Can't be B as this would 1) cause a loop but also 2) it would be the workflow generating the task that triggers another (sub)flow, not the task itself. Workflow-to-task is one-to-many.

Selected Answer: A
A should be the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
A should be the correct answer. Workflows and tasks are not two-way (i.e. a task can trigger a workflow, but this workflow will not trigger the same task - otherwise you have a loop...)

questions.question_text: Tables may be set up with Many to Many relationships. What is a classic example of a scenario where the tables would have many to many relationships?

choices.B: A Task can trigger many Workflows; and a Workflow can trigger many Tasks.
choices.A: Vendors can sell multiple products; and products can be sold by multiple vendors.
choices.C: Requests can contain many Items; and Items can be any item from the catalog.
choices.D: A Configuration Item can belong to multiple Classes, and Classes can contain multiple Configuration Items.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C - this is where you see the full list of activities
C is correct
